MY DBC 17 PC Impressions and ReviewIf your a cricket fan not just cricket gamer this game is a must get, why simply because any cricket scenario under the sun/floodlight  in any era, any place, you will be able to recreate and live it in this game. Want to play in bodyline series you can, want to play pinkball underlights you can, want to play woman cricket which still has the soul and vigour of past era you can. Want to do a Bloackathon on the last day of the test you can, want to Cover drive and break the off side like ganguly or lara you can, or coax that annoying tail end batsman to edge one with the second new ball or edge one from the rough with the old one You can.This is not just a game but a cricket sandbox. TLDR; Cricket fan, Its a definite buy!!!Graphics: 	            The game looks fantastic to simply put, the players look more detailed and real, the lighting in an ODI as the sun goes down and flood lights come on is wonderful. With vintage filters on the game looks a beaut to play withm you can recreat that eras appearance and feel. Animations are more fluid.At max detail in FHD the game looks really pretty.  The grass looks fantastic both on pitch and on outfield. And once you get the community created real teams and stadiums, the game really takes on to next level in cricket simulation.Gameplay:	Batting	: Simply there is not a place on the ground you cant  put the ball through. The batting has greatly improved from previous version with better physics and feel to the shot, plus is more challenging and engaging due to tougher AI bowling. All the drives are a delight to play, just judging and picking that right ball and timeing it to put it away, feels sublime. Improvements From 14 to batting:1.Better physics. feel and stroke variation. straight drives, cover drives are a joy to play.2.Custom batting difficulty, plus you can have indicators appearing slightly before bowler bowls, which helps solve premediation problem folks with slow reflex had with last game3.PRO Cam is stable now and you can play with a still head and feel the ball rushing past you. 4. Precise button for batting really improves in being able to have that checked shot through the gaps, or that little chip shot for four like ponting. 5.Pitch variation is very effective now, and you have to adapt to the conditions more.Pardon the video Quality, my recorder and encoder setings werent good.

Bowling: 	 This is the area that has improved leaps and bounds from the last game, the new controls are intutive and give a great degree of variations to deliveries. As spin bowler its a delight to be able to control flight, bounce to a delivery along with varyign length and speed and you inner warne roars with delight. But what makes it also rewarding is the way AI approaches batting now so you can actually work out the AI with good deliveries and set them up. Improvments from 14 to bowling:1.Intutitve Controls, no more thumb breaking for spin :p2.varied edges 3.AI batting to edges4. pitch and ball conditon play a lot of factor in bowling.Fielding:	         This works well with the brilliant batting and bowling, the new fielder animations are fluid, the slow mo catching for quick catches actually works well with the flow of game, and i liked it more than i thought would. fielding is improved over 14, still has some little quirks here and there, especially in the way the fielder choose the end to throw the ball, could be more quick with stumpings, and run outs. sometimes they work really well and feel amazing, but there are times when they can feel ordinary.AI field sets can be too atacking at times, when they need to defensive. Its more of little quirks getting in the way.But given the Bigant's commitment to the game and the community, and how fast they improve things, im sure the little quirks will be fixed over time.Career Mode: has gotten a huge improvement from 14 you can now play club level crickter before moving upstairs, also tournaments are a part of career. You also have the option to play as a single player or as a team in career before every match, which is a joy. ACADEMY:	        This is has unbelievable improvement. The amount of customoisation is impossible to comprehend just think about thisyou can create [or grab ones created by  others] any player of any gender with any appearance, with any kit you want and play them in any stadium with any appearance you want in any type of format either official or cooked up by you.even that sentance is a disservice to the accademy. The new logo creator and stadium creator have made modding redundant no more muckign aroudn folders and files for pc players and modding for consoles directly. Right now get best works well ootb, but i would recommend putting some time and curating teams to have a better play in the longer run, i would recommend teams by Casper, Friedlele7,  Karolkarol etc.Check planet cricket community threads for more info. A lot of work has been put into this by the community.UI: the game overlay looks good, has a lot of info than 14. The Hud assists themselves are good and dont interefere with gameplay. The only area were UI is lackign is it takes more presses to get something done than in 14 like fielding changes to bring the field eidtor, batsman transparency etc. Again i have have faith in BA that these will be worked on and fixed. Audio: 	        The atmosphere is amazing in stadium, the crowd ambience, the instadium announcer all make it amazing,  the accoustics are excellent, the commenatary in itself is okish not better or bad than any other past cricket game, they do say unrelated things a bit, i personally recommend setting the SFX and crowd ambience high in audio settings and enjoy the atmosphere it creates.Support and Service: 	                      I feel this is should be a part of review of every game nowadays, almost every game  nowadays have bugs, quirks on launch, its how they are responded by the Developer that matters. In that regard Bigant are a gem, they respond quickly and immediately, they listen to each and every complaint about the game patiently from the community, interact with them directly, not through PR but the CEO and the developers directly interact frankly, collect info and improve. They do beta updates with the community take feedback and update with patches regularly, DBC 14 was a testament to this support and DBC17 now is. As one of  members privilaged to be able to access pc version of the game early and having spent a good amount of time i fully recommend the game even if you have 14 already.This game is a tribute to cricket!

												I, for the life of me, cannot understand why all the reviews are positive so far!I cannot stress enough, this game is a downgrade from Don Bradman Cricket 14!!! It would have been more appropriate for the developers to release this as an early access title considering its current state... Every single aspect of this game, aside from its lofty aspirations, is worse than its predecessor!! When my wife played this game for the first time, she stated "It's as if they took all the parts of Don Bradman Cricket 14 that needed fixing, failed at fixing them, and then broke every other part of the game while they were at it"... I have never been so disappointed with a $65 (AUD) purchase in my whole life! A few of my favourite issues with this game are:1) The physics – one of the highlights of DBC 14 for me was the realistic way the ball came onto the bat - fast!! DBC 17 has destroyed this feeling, it feels as if the ball is more inflatable beach ball than cricket ball!! This seems partly due to the speed of both the bat and the ball, which are both far too slow to accurately represent the game of cricket... or physics in general!!2) The bowling controls are in fact less dynamic and allow for less control than DBC 14 (While requiring twice as many buttons to be pressed) - instead of controlling the length of the ball with the timing of the thumbstick movements (A great system which actually required skill to bowl the ball where you wanted to), you simply press a button to choose a length, and a modifier to move it foward or backwards a little... meaning there are 12 exact lengths that can be bowled, and no skill is required to achieve the same length delivery ball after ball... 3) While the graphics and lighting may in fact be "improved/running on a better engine" from the previous version, they do not look better overall - its hard to explain... everything is just too rounded and shiny looking, to the point that IMO, DBC 14 looks better, as it captures depth and shadows better.4) The system for setting fields is massively overcomplicated, as is the UI experience in general!5) There are things wrong with almost every part of this game, fielding, batting, bowling, the UI, the academy... Some of it major, some of it minor, but its guaranteed to annoy the hell out of anyone who enjoys the sport of cricket!!So I will end with this suggestion:- If you are the sort of gamer that is prepared to pay a AAA price for a low-budget indie game, and say things like "quality doesn't matter, I want to support this developer, regardless of how unfinished their games are" and "This game has the potential to be the greatest cricket game of all time!! Who cares if its going to take another 3 years of development to realise this dream!!" and "I am happy to spread lies about the quality of this game" - This is the game for you!!!- If however, like myself, you prefer notions such as "value for money", "honesty" and "Calling a spade a spade", then avoid this game like the plague, as it is unfinished, sh*te, and a complete and utter downgrade from its predecessor!!!

												Don Bradman Cricket 2017: a review......Don Bradman Cricket is the worthy successor to Don Bradman 14. The attention to detail and the depth of gameplay is quite amazing. The fact that you can now choose to play either as a female or male cricketer is fantastic. I myself have been playing the game the last week and can quite clearly say it is the best cricket game ever made; ever! And I have played them all and always been thoroughly dissapointed.  Everyone is entitled to their own opinion and of course eerything depends on wha you are hoping or looking for in a game and whilst DBC still needs some tweaking and polishing it has all the ingredients present to make it a classic and I have full confidence that BA wil do jut that.The Don Bradman series is different because it caters to such a wide range of tastes: want a quick fire 5 over bash? No problem. Want a five day test match? Done! And both variations give a realistic and satisfying game.The level of editing now available is mind-boggeling and thanks to the talents of many in the community you can download your favourite players, kits, teams, bats and even stadiums.I myself am setting up my own custom league and making a number of small town stadium to go along with them. I would never have thought that that would be possible in a cricket game.Another great addition are the game play modifiers so that you can now tweak every aspect of gamkeplay so it suits your own needs: need more time to judge the pace and length of the ball? That is now possible along with a whole array of other modifiers such as bounce, friction, front-foot anticipation....the list goes on!Cricket is a complicated game consisiting of many types of cricket and each area of discipline (batting, bowling and fielding) has its own dynamic and skills: these are really well catered for in DBC17 and you really have the sense of being part of a bigger picture where everything matters down to the tiniest detail.Another plus is that the team making the game are themselves very passionate about the game and have listened intently to to the community, striving to bring the game both the hard-core cricket fan and the casual gamer can enjoy. I think they have done a really good job in presenting players with the possibility to find there own particular niche within the game.They are committed to bringing tweaks and patches where needed and listening for feedback as to where the game needs some good old spit and polish.Having already spent many hours on this game i can highly recommend it to every cricket lover: yes it will take a little bit of learning: but thats what you want out of a game: the satisfaction of developing your skills and seeing that pay-off in the field of play. On the other hand there are so many modifiers and custom modes that you can just strap straight up and bash your way to glory as your favourite cricketing hero.Conclusion: should you get this game? Product received for free
												The PC version of DBC 17 is a sure winner. Graphics are smooth and crisp, lighting is absurdly good and although Big Ant are a small developer on a tight budget they have made every effort imaginable to make this a cricket game for cricket lovers. Gameplay has definitely come a long way with AI being more tactically aware than in the predecessor DBC 14. They judge chases more efficiently and tend to play better cricket all round. Cricket can now be played 360 degrees around the field and shot making is intuitive and fluid. Edges are clearly way more evident with catches through to the keeper a regular occurance. With 3 different settings and customisable sliders for your own personal preference anybody can pick up a controller and enjoy the game of cricket despite you level of play.With a lot of negative feelings towards the initial console release, the developers have made every effort to listen to the customer and fix what they wanted fixed. Customisation in the game is unrivaled with the academy for users to create and share teams, logos, bats, stadiums and players. With literally hundreds of ways to edit and customise every gameplay, match types and tours etc including Day/Night Tests and every other format imaginable, it certainly has enough depth in its modes. Career mode has been deepened and conitnues to be my favourite. Although a lot easier on the eye than DBC 14 the initial screens and UX are not always user friendly and at times can be long winded when navigating, BA have however made steps towards making it easier and I am sure will continue to do so. Commentary is still sometimes one dimensional and repetitive, but James Taylor is a breath of fresh air and a major coup for the game. - Graphics         8/10- Commentary    7/10- Gameplay        8.5/10- Customisation  9.5/10- Modes             9/10- Customisation 10/10In my book a big step up from DBC 14 in many and a good sequel. It’s easily possible to score very quick runs with low skilled batsmen into these gaps. This was a bug in the previous game, so it’s frustrating to see it carry over to this game, three years on.Overall, it’s a great cricket experience. 												TLDR;Pros:-1. Improved gameplay over DBC 142. Great control mechanics3. Highly customisable4. A fun cricket game....Cons:-1. .... which is plagued by lack of production finesse2. Abysmal commentary3. Plenty of in-game glitches, which tend to get frustrating 4. Lots of issues from DBC 14 carried overMy verdict: Buy it if you must have a fun cricket game to play right now, else wait for a decent discount and a couple of patches / updates.7/10DBC 17 comes nearly three years after DBC 14 broke new grounds in creating a fun yet challenging cricket game for all platforms, something which the biggies of the gaming industry *cough*EA*cough* had considered too demeaning for them to take up. DBC 14 was a genuinely fun game, but it had its issues, some of which were never resolved. Of course, the success of DBC 14 meant that the next iteration had to be big enough to live up to the high standards set by the studio.Sadly, I cannot give a convincing thumbs up to this iteration of the game. A lot has improved - batting is much more fluidic and realistic, especially at the tougher difficulty levels (if you are a DBC 14 veteran, don't be afraid to crank up the AI), bowling is tougher than before, but much more rewarding, once you get the hang of it, and fielding has been pushed up a couple of notches for the good. The interface remains simplistic, and focuses on getting you in the game as soon as possible. There are still no licensed players, but the fledgling community should take care of that. The career mode is much more comprehensive now, and slightly less frustrating than before (again, this depends on how it is evolved during the game's) life cycle.However, the improvements end here, at least for now. For a game priced at par with AAA titles, DBC 17 lacks production flair. A little more colour to the presentation would have done wonders, especially in the moments leading up to or after a match. Commentary is abysmal - there is no other word for it - with drab voices, unexcited commentators, and frequently messed up lines. Over time, you will realise how the bad commentary actually kills half the fun to be had out of the match. Animations could have been spruced up much more, and the fluidity could have been worked upon. It's not that the end game is bad, just that three years and a AAA price were enough for anyone to expect all the previous issues ironed out, and substantial improvements put in.While I can easily recommend this game to a DBC newbie / cricket enthusiast (assuming you are okay shelling out this kind of money), I will be hard pressed to do so to anyone who has played DBC 14. The game needs a couple of updates and major patches before it deserves that credit. I will be sure to update my review if and when that happens.
